title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act, under Title X of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, includes sections on short title, definitions, privacy protection for customer information, enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalty, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Act defines terms like "customer" and "customer information of a financial institution." The Financial Information Privacy Act, part of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, defines terms related to customer information of financial institutions, including the definition of a financial institution as an entity providing financial services to customers with accounts or relationships. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines a financial institution as any entity providing financial services to customers with accounts or relationships. This includes depository institutions, loan or finance companies, credit card issuers, operators of credit card systems, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define financial institutions through regulation. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines a financial institution as any entity providing financial services to customers. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define financial institutions through regulation. The Act prohibits obtaining customer information by false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution by making false statements or providing fraudulent documents. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false statements or fraudulent documents with the intent to deceive. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits soliciting someone to obtain customer information from a financial institution under false pretenses. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from this prohibition, as are financial institutions in certain cases. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows financial institutions to obtain customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, and information recovery. The Financial Information Privacy Act permits financial institutions to access customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, and information recovery. The Act also specifies that certain types of customer information available as public records under securities laws are exempt from its provisions. Enforcement of the Act is overseen by the Federal Trade Commission. Enforcement of the Financial Information Privacy Act is overseen by the Federal Trade Commission, with the same power as under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In certain cases, enforcement may be carried out by other agencies such as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and the Federal Reserve for member banks. The Financial Information Privacy Act is enforced by various agencies including the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks, the Federal Reserve for member banks, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for insured banks. The Financial Information Privacy Act is enforced by different agencies for various types of banks and credit unions. This includes the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for insured banks, the Office of Thrift Supervision for savings associations, and the National Credit Union Administration for Federal credit unions. The Financial Information Privacy Act is enforced by different agencies for banks and credit unions, such as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Office of Thrift Supervision, and the National Credit Union Administration. Violations of this act are treated as violations of other laws, and state action can be taken for violations. State action can be taken for violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act, in addition to remedies provided under State law. The chief law enforcement officer of a State or designated official may bring an action to enjoin violations or recover damages on behalf of residents in any appropriate court. State action can be taken for violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act in any United States district court or court of competent jurisdiction. The chief law enforcement officer of a State may bring an action to recover damages on behalf of residents, with damages capped at $1,000 per violation. Successful actions may result in the award of costs and attorney fees. Prior notice must be served to the Federal Trade Commission before taking action. The State must provide written notice to the Federal Trade Commission before taking action for violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act. The FTC or relevant agency has the right to intervene in the action. The Federal Trade Commission or an agency can intervene in actions related to violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act, be heard on all matters, remove the action to the appropriate court, and file petitions for appeal. No provision shall prevent state law enforcement officers from exercising their powers for bringing actions under this subsection. The chief law enforcement officer or designated state official can still conduct investigations and compel witnesses under this subsection. States are limited in taking action if the Federal Trade Commission has initiated a civil action for a violation of the title. "During a civil action for a violation of this title, no State can bring an action against a defendant named in the complaint of the Federal Trade Commission for the same violation. Civil liability applies to any person failing to comply with this title regarding financial institutions or customer information, leading to liability for actual damages." The text outlines the potential liabilities for failing to comply with regulations regarding financial institutions or customer information, including actual damages, additional damages, and attorneys' fees. Additionally, it mentions the criminal penalty for such violations. Sec. 1006 outlines the criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving other illegal activities or large sums of money. Sec. 1007 states that this title does not override state laws unless they are inconsistent, and Sec. 1008 addresses agency guidance. Sec. 1008 addresses agency guidance for Federal banking agencies to assist depository institutions in deterring and detecting prohibited activities under section 1003. Before the end of 18 months from enactment, a report to Congress will be submitted by the Comptroller General in consultation with relevant agencies. The Comptroller General, in consultation with relevant agencies, will submit a report to Congress on the efficacy of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and recommendations for legislative or regulatory actions to protect financial privacy.
